title: Moapa Valley National Wildlife Refuge
text:
The Moapa Valley National Wildlife Refuge (MVNWR) is a protected <a href="wildlife%20refuge">wildlife refuge</a> administered by the <a href="U.S.%20Fish%20and%20Wildlife%20Service">U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service</a>, located in the <a href="Warm%20Springs%20Natural%20Area">Warm Springs Natural Area</a> in the <a href="Moapa%20Valley">Moapa Valley</a> of <a href="Clark%20County%2C%20Nevada">Clark County, Nevada</a>. The refuge is east of <a href="Death%20Valley">Death Valley</a> and northeast of <a href="Las%20Vegas%2C%20Nevada">Las Vegas, Nevada</a>.
The refuge was created as part of the larger <a href="Desert%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge%20Complex">Desert National Wildlife Refuge Complex</a>, on September 10, 1979. The Desert National Wildlife Refuge complex also includes the <a href="Ash%20Meadows%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge">Ash Meadows National Wildlife Refuge</a>, the <a href="Desert%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge">Desert National Wildlife Refuge</a>, and the <a href="Pahranagat%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge">Pahranagat National Wildlife Refuge</a>.
History.
One of the areas of the MVNWR, now called the "Plummer Unit," was a public, family-owned recreational park. A former general manager of the Aladdin Hotel in Las Vegas, Bob Plummer, purchased a parcel of land with an <a href="oasis">oasis</a> of <a href="Washingtonia%20filifera">California Fan Palm</a>s ("Washingtonia filifera") and natural <a href="hot%20spring">hot spring</a>s. It became known as "Desert Oasis Warm Springs." During the 1970s and 80's he converted the property into a spa, resort and retreat enjoyed for over several decades by Las Vegas area families, with fond memories at the "Jewel in the Desert". By 1990 the resort changed from an open-to-the-public venue into a private time-share spa.
The Desert Oasis Warm Springs Resort continued to operate until a wildfire swept through the area in 1994. After the fire, the resort remained unused until 1997 when the property was purchased by <a href="Del%20Webb">Del Webb Inc.</a>, turned over to the Fish and Wildlife Service, and incorporated as part of the Moapa Valley National Wildlife Refuge.
Moapa dace fish.
The refuge was established to provide and protect the <a href="habitat">habitat</a> of the <a href="endangered%20species">endangered species</a> of <a href="Moapa%20dace">Moapa dace</a> of which about 1,900 exist in the <a href="Muddy%20River%20%28Nevada%29">Muddy River</a> area. The habitat on the refuge consists of stream channels feeding the Muddy River including six <a href="hot%20spring">hot spring</a>s emerging near the center of the refuge.
Since the 1990s the dace have been in decline mainly due to <a href="habitat%20destruction">habitat destruction</a> and modification. Nearby groundwater pumping has decreased stream discharge and streamflows and decreased dace habitat. Competition with <a href="introduced%20species">introduced species</a> such as the <a href="Gambusia%20affinis">mosquitofish</a> and <a href="Poecilia%20mexicana">shortfin molly</a> have also added to the dace's decline.
In August, 2005 the <a href="National%20Wildlife%20Refuge%20Association">National Wildlife Refuge Association</a> and again in September, 2005 the <a href="Defenders%20of%20Wildlife">Defenders of Wildlife</a> listed the Refuge as one of the 10 most endangered refuges in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
